image_text: After five years of drought, California was socked by one of its wettest winters in decades. The small city of Oroville saw nearly twice as much precipitation this rain year, through February, as last.
Look at all the ways water flows into the reservoir.
Nothing was flowing into Oroville during the drought.
The chart also shows how no water was inflowing during the drought.
Winter storms in the mountains around Oroville generated a lot of runoff, which poured into the state-run reservoir. The reservoir swelled to its highest level in years.
Look at all the ways water flows out of the reservoir.
With more water flowing into Lake Oroville, dam operators sent more water downstream, into the Feather River.
Look at all the water flowing out.
As the reservoir got closer to filling, operators increased outflows, at least until the lake’s main spillway cracked on Feb. 7.
Look at how the dam was damaged.
Look at a photo of how the dam was damaged.
That means they decided to evacuate people nearby.
Look at a photo of the evacuated people.
Now there are big repairs happening.

While dam managers have been able to sufficiently release water from the lake, through the damaged main spillway, they worry that future runoff could test their success. Snowpack in the mountains is near record highs, and as it melts this spring, the lake’s inflow is likely to be large. Most reservoirs in California are similarly at or near capacity and are releasing large amounts of water downstream.
